title: Advice from San Joaquin County law enforcement: ‘Stay at home and use good common sense’
summary:
State residents who violate the governor’s order could, theoretically, face a fine of up to $1,000 and/or up to six months imprisonment, according to California state law.
But both the San Joaquin County Sheriff’s Office and Stockton Police Department say neither is likely to happen at this point.
As of Friday, San Joaquin County Public Health Services has identified 25 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the county.
Stockton police officials also say the department’s law enforcement priorities will remain protecting "life and property" and it will not take a criminal justice approach to "a public health issue."
Officials warned, however, that the governor’s order is enforceable if necessary, but only as a last resort.

title: China’s lies, and ours
summary:
From the first reported case, on Dec. 1, 2019, until Jan. 5, 2020, the Chinese government engaged in a cover-up.
As National Review’s Jim Geraghty recounted, in early January, China’s National Health Commission forbade reporting on the new disease.
When the lies were no longer tenable, the Chinese government pivoted.
When the lies were no longer tenable, President Trump pivoted.
By consistently downplaying and denying the seriousness of the threat, President Trump cost the American people precious time.

title: Stockton, California, is the most racially and ethnically diverse city in America
summary:
California cities make up seven of the top 10 US urban centers with the most diverse populationsThis article is more than 2 months oldThis article is more than 2 months oldAs American cities become increasingly diverse, the future may look a bit like Stockton, California.

title: Hundreds of Military Explosives Found at California Home Were Replicas
summary:
STOCKTON, Calif. (AP) — Hundreds of military explosive devices found at a California home were replicas, experts determined Friday.
An ordnance disposal team from Travis Air Force Base was called to help deal with the devices and announced on Friday afternoon that they were non-explosive replicas, KCRA-TV reported.
The team also found 25 small flares and fuses that would be removed, the station said.
Police said the man who died in the home didn't have a military background but appeared to have been a collector of military items, KCRA-TV reported.

title: Sheriff's office investigating officer-involved shooting in Stockton
summary:
STOCKTON, Calif. (KTXL) — The San Joaquin County Sheriff’s Office says Monday night a deputy shot at an armed man who had an outstanding warrant out for his arrest.
Around 5:50 p.m., a San Joaquin County deputy and a Stockton officer were surveilling 19-year-old Johnnie Earl Ross on Montclair Street near Pock Lane, according to the sheriff’s office.
The sheriff’s office reports Ross’ arrest warrant stemmed from a gun-related charge and deputies had previously interacted with the 19-year-old during other incidents.
The sheriff’s office says he then “racked the slide, and ejected an unspent round.”“In fear of his safety,” the deputy shot at Ross, wounding him, according to the sheriff’s office.
Ross was hospitalized and on Tuesday was in critical but stable condition, according to the sheriff’s office.

title: Democrats open SJ County party office
summary:
As the election season gains momentum, the Democratic Party is looking to give its San Joaquin County candidates an extra boost by having them work alongside each other.
“We wanted everybody kind of pulling our resources, our talent, our ideas together,” said Lee Columber II, California Democratic Party field coordinator for San Joaquin.
The upcoming election is important, said Cheryl Hays, a San Joaquin County and Tracy Democratic Party member.
Candidates who will be working out of the new Stockton office are officially endorsed by the Democratic Party, letting people know who they are really voting for.
A coordinated effort produces better voter turnout, increases the number of volunteers and avoids duplication of efforts, said Michael Evans, chair of the Fresno County Democratic Party.

title: Stockton police chief releases strategic plan for 2020
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoSTOCKTON, Calif. (KTXL) -- Stockton Police Chief Eric Jones released his new strategic plan Tuesday for law enforcement in the city of Stockton.
"We still need to reduce crime, reduce blight, improve trust in our community and hire a very diverse and professional workforce," Jones said.
"We have the most police officer positions than we have ever had in the history of Stockton," Jones explained.
The police department's strategic plan was created with input from officers and other department staff, along with feedback from the police chief's Community Advisory Board.
"We absolutely know that increased trust within police can reduce crime, specifically violent crime," Jones said.

title: Man dies in Stockton shooting, suspect arrested
summary:

When officers arrived they found a 53-year-old male victim who was found dead at the scene by medics, according to officials.
Investigators discovered the victim lived with 59-year-old Coy Williams and said Willams got into a fight with the victim before allegedly shooting him.

title: SPD's 2020 Strategic Plan: Reduce crime and blight, improve trust
summary:
The Stockton Police Department released its 2020 Strategic Plan last week, outlining a course of action continuing to work toward goals it set forth in its previous three-year plans.
Reducing violent crime, shootings and homicides remains a priority, Jones said.
But homicide rates are on a downward trend in Stockton, despite a slight increase in last year’s numbers.
It’s also more than 50 percent lower than the city’s peak in 2012 at 71, which Jones said was the most homicides Stockton ever had seen.
Jones said reducing homicide rates takes partnerships with community, county, state and federal agencies, as well as disrupting retaliatory group gun violence and building trust between officers and the neighborhoods they patrol.

summary:
STOCKTON — A man who was fatally shot at his south Stockton home after confronting three intruders coming onto his property has been identified by the San Joaquin County Coroner’s Office as 36-year-old Ricardo Aguilar.
On Monday afternoon, Aguilar saw three men attempting to enter his backyard in the 1000 block of East Seventh Street, between South Sacramento and South Union streets four blocks west of South Airport Way, according to police.

title: California and Coronavirus: Eight Cases Are Confirmed in the State
summary:

The patients were on separate State Department-arranged flights that mostly carried American citizens to Marine Corps Air Station Miramar in San Diego.
Four of the state’s cases are in Southern California and four in the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: Victor Mow resigns from Stockton port commission
summary:
STOCKTON — Victor Mow, who hit and killed an 82-year-old man while driving drunk in 2018, officially stepped down from the Port of Stockton Board of Commissioners at the beginning of last month.
Blood drawn later that night at San Joaquin General Hospital revealed Mow had a blood alcohol content of .076 percent.
The San Joaquin County Board of Supervisors is currently accepting applications to replace Mow through Jan. 10, said Rachel Debord, clerk of the board.
The port’s board is made up of seven commissioners; four are appointed by the city of Stockton and three are appointed by San Joaquin County, according to the Port Of Stockton's website.
Anyone looking to apply to become a port commissioner can apply on the San Joaquin County government website, in person or email, Debord said.

title: Flu has killed 105 Californians so far this winter
summary:
So far, 105 people have died from the flu this winter, with 35 of those people dying in the week ending Jan. 11, per the California Department of Public Health data.
That’s exactly a 50% increase in flu deaths in one week, while the other 70 deaths so far this season were spread out from late September to early January.
Meanwhile, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday that 39 children nationwide have died from the flu so far this season.
There’s some good news locally, though: Shasta County Public Health says that so far this season, there haven’t been any flu deaths of children in the county.
Still, adult flu deaths don’t have to be reported to the agency, so it’s unclear whether any adults have died in the county this season.

title: Two killed in fiery crash on Eight Mile Road in Stockton
summary:
STOCKTON, Calif. (KTXL) — Two people were killed Tuesday afternoon in a fiery crash on Eight Mile Road in Stockton.
The California Highway Patrol reports the driver behind the wheel of a silver Infiniti sedan was “driving erratically” in the eastbound lanes of Eight Mile Road near Interstate 5.
The driver lost control of the car while trying to get around traffic and hit a tree, according to officials.
The CHP says two people in the car died after it burst into flames.
Officials have closed all eastbound lanes of Eight Mile Road in front of Oak Grove Regional Park as they investigate the crash scene.

title: Stockton receives state grant to reinvigorate McKinley Park
summary:
The city of Stockton is set to receive an $8.5 million state grant to revitalize McKinley Park in south Stockton.
STOCKTON — McKinley Park in south Stockton will receive a major face-lift thanks to a state grant awarded to the city of Stockton.
On Tuesday, the city learned it will receive $8.5 million to revitalize McKinley Park, at 22 acres the largest municipal park in south Stockton.
The project also calls for renovating two existing sports fields into multi-purpose/soccer fields, renovating existing paths with lighting, renovating one existing parking lot, constructing additional parking spaces and renovating existing landscaping throughout the park.
Darryl Rutherford, executive director of the Reinvent South Stockton Coalition, said the grant is a huge win for Stockton and the new park will go a long way improving the lives of area residents.

title: Stockton Symphony steppin’ out for SJ students
authors: Donald W. Blount Record Staff Writer
summary:
STOCKTON — The numbers rolled off the fingers of conductor Peter Jaffe’s left hand easily.
It was a melding of the mathematics and music Jaffe studied while at Oberlin College many years ago, and the teaching he does as the musical director of the Stockton Symphony.
Only this was the second of three days of “Steppin’ Out,” an annual symphony program aimed at sharing the arts with students.
Jaffe used the time to show students how important and useful fractions are, and also how enjoyable ice cream is, as well as teaching them about music.
The students bubbled as the orchestra played while many adults, who also could not sit still, bobbed along with the music.

summary:

The county health department continues to monitor the individual.
“Cases in the U.S., including this first case in Sacramento County, have primarily been travel-related,” said Dr. Peter Beilenson, Sacramento County Department of Health Services Director.
There are 10 people in California who have tested positive for the virus in lab tests performed by the CDC, the California Department of Public Health said.

Stockton police also said a total of six cars were towed and six referee referrals were given out.

title: Stockton Chinese New Year Celebration will go on as scheduled March 1
summary:
STOCKTON — Organizers of the 2020 Stockton Chinese New Year Celebration plan to hold their event as scheduled in March in downtown Stockton.
Several cities, including Elk Grove and Sacramento, have canceled Chinese Lunar New Year festivities this weekend in an abundance of caution due to the novel coronavirus outbreak in China.
But right now, with the event more than a month away, plans still are in the works to hold the 42nd Stockton Chinese New Year Celebration, Year of the Rat, on March 1 at Stockton Memorial Civic Auditorium.
In San Francisco, which has the country’s most-populated Chinatown, the Chinese New Year Parade remains scheduled for Feb. 8.
Stockton’s Chinese New Year Celebration will begin with a parade at Weber Point Events Center followed by a festival inside Stockton Memorial Civic Auditorium.

title: Stockton police: Driver of suspected stolen car crashes after pursuit ends
summary:
STOCKTON, Calif. (KTXL) — Stockton police said they arrested the driver of a suspected stolen car and his passenger but not before a short pursuit.
The driver originally complied with a traffic stop but police said he then led the officer on a pursuit around 2:20 p.m. Saturday.
Police identified the driver as 19-year-old Julian Medina but did not identify his passenger since he is a 15-year-old boy.
They were arrested for being in possession of a stolen car and resisting arrest, according to police.
Police also said Medina was arrested for battery on an officer while the teenager was additionally arrested on gun charges.

title: One California mayor has tried universal basic income. His advice for Trump: 'Think big'
summary:
One California mayor has tried universal basic income.
His advice for Trump: 'Think big'As the Trump administration and lawmakers in Washington debate cash payments to support Americans during the coronavirus crisis, the mayor of one California city that has experimented with universal basic income has advice.
It’s “heartening” to see a national focus on providing direct cash assistance, said Michael Tubbs, Stockon’s 29-year-old mayor, who championed the city’s basic income experiment.
Direct cash payments are more flexible than a one-size-fits-all government program, and they allow people to adapt to changing needs and new crises.
But even large direct cash payments aren’t a substitute for other kinds of government action, they cautioned.

title: Could coronavirus spread to state’s homeless population?
summary:
The potential for an outbreak among that unsheltered population — both in Sacramento and across California — is beginning to concern some public health officials as the coronavirus spreads.
Though the number of coronavirus cases remains at only a few dozen in the United States, homeless people, in particular, for multiple reasons could be vulnerable to both a quick spread of the illness and to more severe cases.
Some homeless people also move often, making them both hard to reach for treatment and potentially increasing the spread of the virus if they are carriers.
At the state level, however, the Department of Public Health has indicated that it does not see the homeless population as particular point of concern as of now.

title: Toscano Boxing Promotions returns to Stockton, March 21st, headliner ‘Kilo The Kid’
summary:
Northern California promoter Toscano Boxing Promotions returns next week, March 21st at the Stockton Memorial Civic Auditorium in Stockton, California for another night of boxing with tickets available at https://www.ticketon.com/event/FIGHTING-TRADITION/406557?sp=73CK4GThe card is headlined by Quilisto “Kilo the Kid” Madera (12-2, 6KOs), a major ticket seller in the Stockton area, who recently signed with Toscano Boxing Promotions, taking on Christian Aguirre (8-7, 4KOs), who is best known for knocking out Joey Alday Jr. two years ago, in a six-round bout.

Lightweight Jose “Karma” Alvarado (4-0, 4KOs) of Mexico, who recently signed with Toscano Promotions and is known for big power will face a very experienced opponent in Mark John Yap (30-15, 15KOs) in a six-round bout.
Also on the card super bantamweight Jose Carrillo (7-0-1, 6KOs) of Manteca, Ca, will face Luis Valdes (6-3-1, 2KOs), Stockton’s own lightweight Wade Jones (3-0, 2KOs) will face Phillip Bounds (0-4) in a four-round bout, Toscano Boxing Promotions signed fighter Giovannie Gonzalez (10-4, 8KOs) will face undefeated Brandon Cortez (5-0, 4KOs) in a six-round fight, super flyweight Marco Arroyo (2-1, 1KO) of Stockton, Ca, will face Cesar Sustaita in a four-round bout, bantamweight Vincent Avina (3-0-1, 3KOs) of Manteca, Ca will face Fernando Ibarra De Anda (2-3) of Fairfield, Ca, bantamweight Ivan Garcia (5-0, 5KOs) will face Nestor Varela (1-0, 1KO) and light heavyweight Nathan Sharp (4-2, 4KOs) will face Daniel Flores (0-2)The card is being put together by matchmaker Manuel Diaz.

summary:
An infant was killed in a crash over the weekend after a San Joaquin County sheriff’s deputy rear-ended a vehicle and caused the driver to lose control, authorities said.
The deputy was driving a patrol cruiser north on Interstate 5 near Charter Way in Stockton when the vehicle rammed into a woman’s Ford sedan shortly after 10:30 p.m. Saturday, according to a news release from the San Joaquin County Sheriff’s Department.
After the car came to a stop, the deputy removed the child from the vehicle and began performing CPR, sheriff’s officials said.
Both the woman and the deputy were taken to area hospitals with injuries, while the infant was flown to a children’s center.
The woman was in critical condition as of Sunday afternoon, according to reporting from the Stockton Record.

title: Stockton, Tracy, West Sacramento Listed On PG&E Shutoff Map By Mistake
summary:

With no fixed address and little trust in the government, the homeless population has always been notoriously difficult to track.
While the census falls under the umbrella of the federal Census Bureau in Washington, jurisdictions have the option to form their own committees to work with the regional offices – something the federal bureau has recommended.
Before the coronavirus crisis, the federal Census Bureau planned on counting people experiencing homelessness from 30 March to 1 April.

title: Pacific names 'truly visionary' president
summary:
STOCKTON — University of the Pacific wants to be more innovative to effectively navigate the challenges in a changing world.

title: California fire season likely to last through December, with no rain in sight
summary:
Within seconds — fanned by the most potent Santa Ana winds of the season — the blaze roared to life with immense speed, chewing through thousands of acres of bone-dry brush and eventually consuming homes.
However, experts caution the blaze may be a preview of what could be a long season of devastating fires amid gusty winds and dry conditions.
A report from the National Interagency Fire Center, released Friday, predicts a higher-than-normal chance for other large fires in Southern California through December, with a late start to the rainy season looking increasingly likely.
However, Southern California hasn’t had significant rain in seven months, and meteorologists say there’s no clear sign of rain anywhere in the forecast through at least mid-November.
Typically, October sees about six days of Santa Ana wind conditions, while November sees nine and December and January have 10 and 11, respectively.

title: CA Cities Rank Among Most Expensive For Rent: LIST
summary:
CALIFORNIA — Rent costs are on the rise across the nation, according to the first National Rent Report of 2020, compiled by Apartment List.
Nationally, rent costs increased 1.4 percent from December 2018 to December 2019; however, some cities actually are bucking the trend and seeing rent costs fall.
According to the report, rent increased 1.1 percent from December 2018 to December 2019.
According to the report, Mesa, Arizona, had the fastest year-over-year rent growth among cities with a population of 250,000 or more.
In 2019, rent in Mesa increased 5.1 percent.

title: Editorial: Dead Dogs and Toxic Fish: Welcome to Stockton, a City Choking on California Water Policy
summary:
Stockton is a city simultaneously in recovery and under stress.
The city’s fate is linked inextricably with the San Joaquin River, which runs through town after its long trip down the western slope of the Sierra and a sharp turn north through the San Joaquin Valley.
Much of the water upstream is diverted for agriculture, although a legal settlement ensures that the river no longer runs dry.
Additional diversions at the downriver end — this time for urban as well as agricultural use — greatly reduce the amount of water that actually makes it through the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta, the San Francisco Bay and then the Pacific.
It is as if one of the state’s two great arteries (the other being the Sacramento River) is detached from its heart.

title: Police holiday retail theft operation leads to 14 arrests
summary:
STOCKTON — A coordinated holiday retail theft mission led to multiple arrests at two shopping malls and a large retailer in north Stockton on Thursday, according to the Stockton Police Department.
The effort recovered a total of $1,400 worth of merchandise from Target and Weberstown and Sherwood malls on Pacific Avenue and resulted in 10 adult and four juvenile arrests, police said.
Stockton Police Strategic Community Officers implemented the special enforcement operation in conjunction with Weberstown Mall security and both JCPenney’s and Target’s loss prevention.
Unmarked cars and patrol vehicles were positioned in and around the malls and Target store, police said.
The juvenile arrests consisted of two males, 15 and 16, and two females, 15 and 17, police said.

title: Water in the bank: Coalition of agencies develops ‘historic’ sustainable groundwater plan
summary:
Each Groundwater Sustainability Plan should outline how the individual agency will achieve groundwater sustainability by 2040 and include measurable objectives and milestones in five-year increments.
It requires groundwater sustainability agencies to develop specific plans that result in sustainable groundwater use within 20 years for groundwater basins designated by the state as medium- or high-priority.
The ESJGWA prepared a draft Groundwater Sustainability Plan in July in order to receive public comment and has considered many of those comments in creating its final plan.
The ESJGWA includes the following 16 Groundwater Sustainability Agencies: Central Delta Water Agency; Central San Joaquin Water Conservation District; city of Lodi; city of Manteca; city of Stockton; Eastside San Joaquin GSA (composed of Calaveras County Water District, Stanislaus County and Rock Creek Water District); Linden County Water District; Lockeford Community Services District; North San Joaquin Water Conservation District; Oakdale Irrigation District; San Joaquin County/No.
2 (with participation from California Water Service Co. Stockton District; South Delta Water Agency; South San Joaquin GSA (composed of South San Joaquin Irrigation District including Woodward Reservoir, city of Ripon and city of Escalon); Stockton East Water District; and Woodbridge Irrigation District.

title: California Is Booming. Why Are So Many Californians Unhappy?
summary:
But today it has a new problem.
For all its forward-thinking companies and liberal social and environmental policies, the state has mostly put higher-value jobs and industries in expensive coastal enclaves, while pushing lower-paid workers and lower-cost housing to inland areas like the Central Valley.
That helps explain why the state has lost more than a million residents to other states since 2006, and why the population growth rate for the year that ended July 1 was the lowest since 1900.
“What’s happening in California right now is a warning shot to the rest of the country,” said Jim Newton, a journalist, historian and lecturer on public policy at the University of California, Los Angeles.
You also can see it in the stories of people like Ms. Johnson and other highly educated workers who have gone elsewhere.

title: SJ Sheriff’s Office launching protocol investigation into incident at jail
summary:
STOCKTON — San Joaquin County Sheriff Patrick Withrow has launched a multi-agency protocol investigation into an incident earlier this month that involved a subject booked into San Joaquin County Jail.
The Stockton Police Department and the San Joaquin County District Attorney’s Office will assist the protocol investigation, a procedure that is invoked on serious matters that involve officers usually with use of force or when impropriety is suspected.
According to the sheriff’s preliminary investigative reports, Servin refused to answer medical screening questions and was taken to a holding cell.
On Thursday, the Sheriff’s Office released a video that shows Servin being booked then entering the holding cell with no apparent signs of physical injuries.
San Joaquin County Sheriff’s custody officers are not issued body-worn cameras due to the cost, Withrow said.

title: Lincoln trustees reject controversial charter school proposal
summary:
STOCKTON — The Lincoln Unified School District has voted to reject Aspire Public Schools’ petition to open a charter school in the district in a meeting that went late into the night.
Board members expressed appreciation for the passion for quality education that the individuals on both side of the issue displayed.
“I agree that we all have our children’s interest at heart,” Trustee Kathleen Solari said before the final vote.
In addition to Solari, Trustees Tony Yadon and Jenny Van DePol were at the meeting.
Aspire officials said they will appeal the rejection to the San Joaquin County Office of Education.

summary:
One lane of eastbound Highway 120 was shut down for about two hours Monday after a three-vehicle collision just west of Highway 99, the California Highway Patrol reported.
Just after noon, CHP responded to a collision between a Chevy pickup, Dodge utility truck and big rig on eastbound Highway 120, according to CHP Stockton’s Facebook page.
The driver of the pickup was transported to an area hospital with major injuries.
It is unknown if drugs or alcohol played a role in the collision, the CHP said.

title: Deputies investigating suspicious death on Stockton Boulevard
summary:
Around 6:30 a.m., someone called authorities about an injured and unresponsive woman who was found 50 feet from Stockton Boulevard near Pomegranate Avenue.
Detectives and crime scene investigators spent hours processing the area around where the body of the woman in her 50s was found.
"She's a regular, a regular homeless person," said Joe Gardena, who runs the laundromat near where the woman died.
Deputies noticed some minor injuries to her body, which was enough to declare her death suspicious.
A local resident who did not want to be identified said his friend saw the woman around 3 a.m. Monday.

title: Pickup truck drives away after hitting, killing 71-year-old woman in Stockton
summary:
STOCKTON, Calif. (KTXL) — A woman died Thursday night in Stockton after she was struck by a pickup truck.
The Stockton Police Department says the 71-year-old woman was walking on West Benjamin Holt Drive near Leesburg Place when she was hit.
She died at the scene after the pickup truck drove away, according to police.
The police department says it does not know if alcohol or drugs were factors in the hit-and-run crash.
All lanes of West Benjamin Holt Drive have reopened following the crash.
